newsitem.title: FINLAND: FINLAND WANTS LOWER VAT FOR JOB-INTENSIVE SERVICES.
newsitem.headline: FINLAND WANTS LOWER VAT FOR JOB-INTENSIVE SERVICES.

text.p: Finland will try to change EU regulations to make it possible to lower value-added tax paid by labour-intensive services and so boost employment, Prime Minister Paavo Lipponen said on Wednesday.

"The government is working towards making it possible to change European Union regulations so that the value-added tax rate of labour-intensive services could be lowered and in this way strengthen conditions for employment," Lipponen told a meeting of the Union of Commercial Employees in Finland.
"Taxes can, however, be lowered only if the state finances permit," he added according to a copy of his prepared speech.

At home, the government would proceed on its staked out course to reduce by various means the so called tax wedge, or the gap between employers' labour costs and the disposable income of employees. The speech gave no details.
The aim is to improve the service sector's competitiveness and employment prospects, Lipponen said.
"In the future, employment can best increase in services," he said, noting two thirds of Finns at work were already service sector employees.
In his speech, Lipponen also repeated the government's commitment to Economic and Monetary Union (EMU).
